author: Robert Harley
title: New supermarket for foodies in MLC Centre makeover
text:
Impression of the new IGA Romeo's boutique supermarket in Sydney's MLC Centre. Supplied Share on twitter by Robert Harley The GPT Group and QIC, co-owners of Sydney's landmark MLC Centre, have signed up an IGA Romeo's Food Hall as part of the $165 million transformation of the retail facilities at the base of the tower.
The owner of IGA Romeo's Food Hall, Joseph Romeo, said the 1000 sq m store had been designed to accommodate the changing demographic of the city â€“ for city workers, commuters, shoppers and residents.
"IGA's Romeo's Food Hall is the next step up in retailing for the Group," he said. "The supermarket will tailor its offer to inner city consumers, with a focus on fresh meal solutions and healthy produce, all at competitive prices," he said.
GPT's head of investment management for office, David Burgess, said the the arrival of the IGA Romeo's Food Hall would further build on the MLC Centre's position as a focal point for eating, shopping and socialising in the city.
GPT and QIC are upgrading the MLC Centre in stages.
The first stage, now nearing completion, is a $15 million rework of a "new look" Food Court and the new IGA Romeo's Food Hall.
New retailers in the Food Court include Neil Perry's Burger Project, due to open in time for Christmas along with Bun Me , Schnitz , Top Juice , Sumo Salad's Green Label concept and "Famous Fish Co" by Costi.
Direct link to railway station
 The IGA Romeo's Food Hall, which has been leased for 10 years with option, will take over space most recently occupied by Harvey Norman but upgraded with a direct connection to the Martin Place rail station.
Mr Burgess said the IGA Romeo's Food Hall, would operate on extended trading hours, from 6am to 10 pm, seven days a week.
"The changes will boost the MLC Centre's nighttime and weekend offering, complementing its traditionally strong trading during the CBD lunchtime period," he said.
The Romeo Group, which was founded in 1987, provides retail services to 29 Foodland, IGA, Super IGA and Organic Wholefoods supermarkets in NSW and South Australia.
The second stage of the MLC Centre transformation is a $150 million upgrade now awaiting approval from the Council of the City of Sydney.
It would create a luxury retail precinct, with a reworked frontage to Castlereagh and King Streets, as well as a new cafe and bar precinct on Martin Place, and a new entrance to the commercial tower, as well as an upgraded Theatre Royal, to be operated by the global Ambassador Theatre Group.
